Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Selective Catalytic Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of Wood Biomass to Market Driven High Value Phenolic Chemicals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/ commercial potential of this project is the development of a catalytic process for the selective production of high value specialty chemicals from lignin. 70 million tons lignin waste, generated by paper and pulp industries and biorefineries annually. While lignin is a rich source of aromatic building block chemicals that can lessen our dependence on petroleum, its selective deconstruction into aromatic chemicals without affecting the value of carbohydrate is a big challenge. The proposed technology provides a unique solution to this challenge in which lignin constituent of wood biomass and municipal wood chips is selectively converted into two high value specialty phenolic compounds in one-step with the simultaneous production of reactive cellulose and xylose. The markets for the lignin derived phenols and their secondary products (isoeugenol, vanillin, dimethoxylphenol) are over $1.1 billion dollars per year of available market. Currently these chemicals are manufactured from high cost clove-oil and petroleum feedstock. If techno-economic analysis for large scale production is favorable, this one-step technology will greatly benefit the paper and pulp industries and biorefineries by generating value from lignin.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will evaluate and establish the commercial feasibility and economic viability of this unique technology by demonstrating a more accurate economic analysis, process design and separation methods, and validating the products specifications for the target application. The current biorefinery processes make full use of the carbohydrate fractions of wood for the production of cellulosic ethanol and fermentable sugars. However, because of lack of effective technology for breaking the recalcitrant lignin, this fraction accounting for an average 25-30 wt% of the plant mass is largely underutilized. This one-step catalytic technology adds unique value by producing high value chemicals, increasing the overall carbon efficiency, while simultaneously delignifying biomass without the need for excess water.

POR.DRECONTENT:
About 70 million tons of wood lignin is annually generated by paper pulping and biorefinery industries as a by-product. Lignin is a rich source for natural aromatic building blocks and contains about 40% of the total carbon value of plants that can be upgraded to high value specialty chemicals, performance products and pharmaceutical ingrediants. However, because of lack of effective technology, more than 98% of lignin is currently burned for only heat values. Using the SBIR Phase I and IB financial support from the National Science Foundation, Spero Energy has developed proprietary technologies for one-step selective conversion of natural and sustainable sourced wood lignin into dihydroeugenol (DHE), 4-propylsyringol and their propenyl derivatives such as isoeugenol without negatively affecting the carbohydrate fractions. DHE, 4-propylsyringol and isoeugenol are high value aroma chemicals for food flavorings and fragrances, and are promising ingredients for cosmetic products, specialty chemicals, performance products, and natural insecticides and herbicides. Using the afformentioned grants, Spero Energy has achieved several critical objectives and milestones towards commercialization of the lignin conversion conversion  and products, which includes (1) identification and evaluation of inexpensive and earth abundant metal based catalyst, (2) catalyst stability and recyclability study, (3) products separation and (4) quality analysis of the separated products for the use in fragrance formulations and food flavorings. This process, based on proprietary technology, was further scaled up to produce commercial standard high purity products from wood lignin.
